title: Hendrix Font
content:
Does anyone know what this font is?

[http://i22.ebayimg.com/04/i/05/4d/30/68\_1\_b.JPG](http://web.archive.org/web/20141122183724/http:/i22.ebayimg.com/04/i/05/4d/30/68_1_b.JPG "http://i22.ebayimg.com/04/i/05/4d/30/68\_1\_b.JPG")
author: oneninetwo

comments.content: evidently not a font but hand drawn lettering...

I think this example is the dictionary illustrations under **not a font.**

Sorry for the sarcastic tone, but this is definitely hand-lettered.
Yeah, I realized this. But, do you know of anyone who has recreated the font based on this artwork?

There is Scriptorium's [Hendrix](http://web.archive.org/web/20141122183724/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/scriptorium/hendrix/), but it's not really the same.

You may find something in a similar style by searching ["psychedelic"](http://web.archive.org/web/20141122183724/http:/www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=psychedelic) or ["nouveau"](http://web.archive.org/web/20141122183724/http:/www.myfonts.com/search?search%5Btext%5D=nouveau) on MyFonts.com.

Many of the artists and designers that produced posters for the psychedelic 60s were inspired by posters from the 1920s -- 1930s plus later nineteenth century "circus" types. The difference being that things become a little "liquidy" when you are _trippin'_, the result being the wonderful intertwined and melting letterforms.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141122183724im_/http:/typophile.com/files/filmore1.jpg)

[Victor Moscoso](http://web.archive.org/web/20141122183724/http:/www.victormoscoso.com/) was one of the more prolific designers of the genre.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141122183724im_/http:/typophile.com/files/filmore2.jpg)

The [The Bindweed Press](http://web.archive.org/web/20141122183724/http:/www.sixtiesposters.com/fd36.htm), San Francisco printed the bulk of the Avalon and Filmore concert posters.

[SixtiesPosters.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20141122183724/http:/www.sixtiesposters.com/familydog1.htm) is a great source for info on designers and posters.

Poster by Alfred Roller, Vienna 1903

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141122183724im_/http:/typophile.com/files/aroller.jpg)

Hmmmm... see any similarities in Victor Moscoso's 1967 poster?

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141122183724im_/http:/typophile.com/files/filmore3.jpg)

which later spawned [Mojo](http://web.archive.org/web/20141122183724/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/mojo/) by Jim Parkinson

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141122183724im_/http:/typophile.com/files/mojo-parkinson.png)
